# Objective

This codebook aims to provide a standardized method for coding all the concepts developed by the World Justice Project’s Access to Justice team from the Legal Needs Survey. These concepts are designed to assess people's experiences within a country when resolving a justiciable problem.

# Legal Needs Survey

## What is a legal needs survey?

A legal needs survey is a large-scale empirical survey that examines the public’s experience with justiciable problems—civil legal issues that individuals may or may not recognize as legal and that can be addressed through formal or informal channels.

-   These surveys explore how people encounter and resolve legal problems, focusing on access to justice, sources of advice and representation, dispute resolution processes, the trajectory of the resolution process, and the broader social and economic hardships associated with legal issues.

# People’s Journeys to Justice

## Access to Appropriate Information and Advice

For the purposes of this study, an individual is considered to have access to information and advice if they reported knowing where to obtain reliable information and guidance to help resolve their legal problem.

## Measurement Framework {.smaller}

<br> **Universe**: People who experienced a legal problem in the previous two years. <br> <br>

## Access to Adequate Assistance and Representation

Access to Assistance and Representation refers to the extent to which individuals facing a legal problem are able to obtain appropriate advice or representation from qualified sources—such as lawyers, professional advisers, or legal aid services—or do not require such assistance to resolve their issue.

# Access to Dispute Resolution Mechanisms (When Needed) {.smaller}

This indicator measures the proportion of individuals who needed access to a third-party dispute resolution mechanism and were able to obtain it to address a justice problem. It reflects people’s effective access to formal and informal institutions that can adjudicate, mediate, or otherwise intervene to help resolve disputes — a core dimension of access to justice and of Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) Indicator 16.3.3.

Dispute Resolution Mechanisms (DRMs) include a broad range of entities such as courts and tribunals, government offices or agencies, ombudsmen, mediators, arbitration and conciliation bodies, complaint or appeal offices, police, and community or religious authorities.

## Fairness of the Resolution Process

This indicator measures the extent to which individuals who have completed the resolution of a legal problem perceive that the process leading to the outcome was fair to all parties involved, regardless of the result itself. It captures people’s subjective assessment of procedural fairness—including impartial treatment, equal opportunity to present their case, and respect throughout the process.

## Timeliness of the Resolution Process {.smaller}

This indicator measures whether a respondent’s legal problem was resolved within one year from the time it began. It captures people’s experience with the speed and efficiency of dispute resolution processes, reflecting a core dimension of people-centered justice.

The indicator is derived from the reported start and end (or abandonment) dates of the justice problem, based on the following questions:

Q24.2 – “Roughly what month and year did the issue start or happen?” (Includes “Don’t know” as a valid response option.)

Q24.3 – “And roughly what month and year was the issue done with, in that it was resolved or all had given up trying to resolve it further?” (Includes “Don’t know” as a valid response option; responses cannot precede September 2023.)

The duration between the start and end dates is calculated in months.

1 (Timely) = The problem was resolved or abandoned in less than one year.

0 (Not timely) = The process lasted one year or longer, or the respondent answered “Don’t know.”

## Outcome of the Resolution Process

This indicator measures whether individuals who experienced a justice problem were ultimately able to resolve it, regardless of the method or channel used. It reflects people’s success in achieving closure or resolution for their justice problems and serves as a direct outcome measure of access to justice.
